summary: the incubation period is the delay from infection until onset of symptoms, and varies from person to person. we analyzed data of period of exposure on 395 human cases of laboratory-confirmed influenza A(H7N9) virus infection in a Bayesian framework. fatal cases of sARS coronavirus and MERS coronavirus had shorter incubation periods when compared with non-fatal cases. underlying diseases that predispose to adverse clinical outcome may also impact the incubation period and subsequent disease severity. the nhs commission determined that the collection of data from A(H7N9) cases was part of a continuing public health investigation of a notifiable infectious disease. a simple approach to estimate the incubation period distribution from interval-censored data is to impute the midpoint of the exposure interval for each patient. however, this approach is likely to overestimate incubation period distributions which tend to be right-skewed [2] logistic regression model where death was the binary response variable. predictors included age, sex, geographical location, underlying conditions and the incubation time Ti of each patient. f and F be the pdf and cdf of the incubation period. i q i d i ( 1 q i ) 1 d i (2) where di = 1 if case i died from the disease and 0 otherwise;
